abstracts.cdata!:
The Fundamental School Quality Project
            of Timor-Leste had the following ratings: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned included:
            1) Project implementation periods (project duration) should
            be realistically set to support accurate estimates of the
            time required to fully implement all the activities planned
            for the project; 2) When projects fail to make adequate
            progress, it is important that both the Bank and the
            Borrower/Grantee quickly understand and agree that the
            project has a problem; 3) The introduction of a new language
            of instruction to a national school system requires careful
            review and attention before policies are established and
            implemented; 4) Nationally employed consultants should be
            carefully selected through a vetted process with at least
            three qualified candidates; 5) In the education sector, the
            use of an independent Project Management Unit (PMU) that
            operate outside the authority of the Ministry of Education
            is often problematic; 6) In the interests of efficiency and
            the establishing of an immediate capacity for a project to
            have an impact, it is better if facility designs,
            construction programs and associated procurement concerns
            can be reviewed, evaluated and agreed in advance of project
            effectiveness; 7) Where large numbers of similar schools are
            to be built or rehabilitated by an inexperienced Ministry in
            association with inexperienced contractors, there is a
            strong case for the development of a 'universal'
            (but adaptable) building design; and 8) The introduction of
            new language(s) must be carefully planned, monitored and
            evaluated to ensure that the transition is being effectively
            introduced and implemented - quality of instruction is
            critical as the timely provision of appropriate learning
            materials. Teachers must be trained to use new materials and
            to deliver the new language.

repnme.cdata!: East Timor - Fundamental School Quality Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fundamental School Quality Project,
            as the second phase of the Trust Fund for East Timor (TFET),
            will specifically support the United Nations Transitional
            Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) in maintaining the
            level of primary education enrollment, restore junior
            secondary enrollment, and, pursue the quality education
            recovery, through physical rehabilitation of facilities, and
            provision of textbooks and instructional material. The
            project's main components will: 1) restore and/or
            construct schools, upgrading facilities from basic
            operational, to fundamental quality, including basic
            teaching equipment. Through the "escola basica", a
            basic education system will integrate the primary and junior
            secondary school concept at the district level, to include
            quality resources such as facilities, and libraries, as well
            as training and communal cultural events. This will be
            accomplished through a site selection criteria where no
            squatters reside on site, certified by the Land and Property
            Commission that no claim on the land is pending; 2) provide
            textbooks, and teachers guides, including teaching and
            learning material, in particular science and mathematics
            instructional material; 3) disseminate information to
            encourage community participation, in collaboration with
            nongovernmental organizations to assist in environmental and
            health issues, supported by technical assistance in social
            mobilization programs; 4) support policy implications of the
            escola basica, finance studies pertaining to the education
            sector, language instruction, and teacher training; and, 5)
            provide project management, supported by experts on
            educational coordination, architecture, procurement, and
            financial management issues.
